column2: My uncle paid without a remark: a man who is starting for the centre of the earth need not be particular about a few rix dollars.

column2: This point being settled, Hans gave the signal, and we soon left Stapi behind us.

column2: CHAPTER XV.
column3: CHAPTER fifteen.

column2: SNAEFELL AT LAST

column2: Snaefell is 5,000 feet high.
column3: Snaefell is five thousand feet high.

column2: Its double cone forms the limit of a trachytic belt which stands out distinctly in the mountain system of the island.
column3: Its double cone forms the limit of a trachytic belt which stands out distinctly in the mountain system of the island.

column2: From our starting point we could see the two peaks boldly projected against the dark grey sky; I could see an enormous cap of snow coming low down upon the giant's brow.
column3: From our starting point we could see the two peaks boldly projected against the dark grey sky; I could see an enormous cap of snow coming low down upon the giant's brow.

column2: We walked in single file, headed by the hunter, who ascended by narrow tracks, where two could not have gone abreast.

column2: There was therefore no room for conversation.

column3: After we had passed the basaltic wall of the fiord of Stapi we passed over a vegetable fibrous peat bog, left from the ancient vegetation of this peninsula.

column2: As a true nephew of the Professor Liedenbrock, and in spite of my dismal prospects, I could not help observing with interest the mineralogical curiosities which lay about me as in a vast museum, and I constructed for myself a complete geological account of Iceland.
column3: As a true nephew of the Professor Liedenbrock, and in spite of my dismal prospects, I could not help observing with interest the mineralogical curiosities which lay about me as in a vast museum, and I constructed for myself a complete geological account of Iceland.

column2: This most curious island has evidently been projected from the bottom of the sea at a comparatively recent date.
column3: This most curious island has evidently been projected from the bottom of the sea at a comparatively recent date.

column2: Possibly, it may still be subject to gradual elevation.
column3: Possibly, it may still be subject to gradual elevation.

column2: If this is the case, its origin may well be attributed to subterranean fires.
column3: If this is the case, its origin may well be attributed to subterranean fires.

column2: Therefore, in this case, the theory of Sir Humphry Davy, Saknussemm's document, and my uncle's theories would all go off in smoke.

column2: This hypothesis led me to examine with more attention the appearance of the surface, and I soon arrived at a conclusion as to the nature of the forces which presided at its birth.
column3: This hypothesis led me to examine with more attention the appearance of the surface, and I soon arrived at a conclusion as to the nature of the forces which presided at its birth.

column2: Iceland, which is entirely devoid of alluvial soil, is wholly composed of volcanic tufa, that is to say, an agglomeration of porous rocks and stones.
column3: Iceland, which is entirely devoid of alluvial soil, is wholly composed of volcanic tufa, that is to say, an agglomeration of porous rocks and stones.

column2: Before the volcanoes broke out it consisted of trap rocks slowly upraised to the level of the sea by the action of central forces.
column3: Before the volcanoes broke out it consisted of trap rocks slowly upraised to the level of the sea by the action of central forces.

column2: The internal fires had not yet forced their way through.

column2: But at a later period a wide chasm formed diagonally from south-west to north-east, through which was gradually forced out the trachyte which was to form a mountain chain.
column3: But at a later period a wide chasm formed diagonally from south-west to north-east, through which was gradually forced out the trachyte which was to form a mountain chain.

column2: No violence accompanied this change; the matter thrown out was in vast quantities, and the liquid material oozing out from the abysses of the earth slowly spread in extensive plains or in hillocky masses.
column3: No violence accompanied this change; the matter thrown out was in vast quantities, and the liquid material oozing out from the abysses of the earth slowly spread in extensive plains or in hillocky masses.

column2: To this period belong the felspar, syenites, and porphyries.
column3: To this period belong the felspar, syenites, and porphyries.

column2: But with the help of this outflow the thickness of the crust of the island increased materially, and therefore also its powers of resistance.
column3: But with the help of this outflow the thickness of the crust of the island increased materially, and therefore also its powers of resistance.

column2: It may easily be conceived what vast quantities of elastic gases, what masses of molten matter accumulated beneath its solid surface whilst no exit was practicable after the cooling of the trachytic crust.
column3: It may easily be conceived what vast quantities of elastic gases, what masses of molten matter accumulated beneath its solid surface whilst no exit was practicable after the cooling of the trachytic crust.

column2: Therefore a time would come when the elastic and explosive forces of the imprisoned gases would upheave this ponderous cover and drive out for themselves openings through tall chimneys. column3: Therefore a time would come when the elastic and explosive forces of the imprisoned gases would upheave this ponderous cover and drive out for themselves openings through tall chimneys. Hence then the volcano would distend and lift up the crust, and then burst through a crater suddenly formed at the summit or thinnest part of the volcano.

column2: To the eruption succeeded other volcanic phenomena.
column3: To the eruption succeeded other volcanic phenomena.

column2: Through the outlets now made first escaped the ejected basalt of which the plain we had just left presented such marvellous specimens.
column3: Through the outlets now made first escaped the ejected basalt of which the plain we had just left presented such marvellous specimens.

column2: We were moving over grey rocks of dense and massive formation, which in cooling had formed into hexagonal prisms.
column3: We were moving over grey rocks of dense and massive formation, which in cooling had formed into hexagonal prisms.

column2: Everywhere around us we saw truncated cones, formerly so many fiery mouths.
column3: Everywhere around us we saw truncated cones, formerly so many fiery mouths.

column2: After the exhaustion of the basalt, the volcano, the power of which grew by the extinction of the lesser craters, supplied an egress to lava, ashes, and scoriae, of which I could see lengthened screes streaming down the sides of the mountain like flowing hair.
column3: After the exhaustion of the basalt, the volcano, the power of which grew by the extinction of the lesser craters, supplied an egress to lava, ashes, and scoriae, of which I could see lengthened screes streaming down the sides of the mountain like flowing hair.

column2: Such was the succession of phenomena which produced Iceland, all arising from the action of internal fire; and to suppose that the mass within did not still exist in a state of liquid incandescence was absurd; and nothing could surpass the absurdity of fancying that it was possible to reach the earth's centre.
column3: Such was the succession of phenomena which produced Iceland, all arising from the action of internal fire; and to suppose that the mass within did not still exist in a state of liquid incandescence was absurd; and nothing could surpass the absurdity of fancying that it was possible to reach the earth's centre.

column2: So I felt a little comforted as we advanced to the assault of Snaefell.
column3: So I felt a little comforted as we advanced to the assault of Snaefell.

column2: The way was growing more and more arduous, the ascent steeper and steeper; the loose fragments of rock trembled beneath us, and the utmost care was needed to avoid dangerous falls.
column3: The way was growing more and more arduous, the ascent steeper and steeper; the loose fragments of rock trembled beneath us, and the utmost care was needed to avoid dangerous falls.

column2: Hans went on as quietly as if he were on level ground; sometimes he disappeared altogether behind the huge blocks, then a shrill whistle would direct us on our way to him.
column3: Hans went on as quietly as if he were on level ground; sometimes he disappeared altogether behind the huge blocks, then a shrill whistle would direct us on our way to him.

column2: Sometimes he would halt, pick up a few bits of stone, build them up into a recognisable form, and thus made landmarks to guide us in our way back.
column3: Sometimes he would halt, pick up a few bits of stone, build them up into a recognisable form, and thus made landmarks to guide us in our way back.

column2: A very wise precaution in itself, but, as things turned out, quite useless.
column3: A very wise precaution in itself, but, as things turned out, quite useless.

column2: Three hours' fatiguing march had only brought us to the base of the mountain.
column3: Three hours' fatiguing march had only brought us to the base of the mountain.

column2: There Hans bid us come to a halt, and a hasty breakfast was served out.
column3: There Hans bid us come to a halt, and a hasty breakfast was served out.

column2: My uncle swallowed two mouthfuls at a time to get on faster.
column3: My uncle swallowed two mouthfuls at a time to get on faster.

column2: But, whether he liked it or not, this was a rest as well as a breakfast hour and he had to wait till it pleased our guide to move on, which came to pass in an hour.
column3: But, whether he liked it or not, this was a rest as well as a breakfast hour and he had to wait till it pleased our guide to move on, which came to pass in an hour.

column2: The three Icelanders, just as taciturn as their comrade the hunter, never spoke, and ate their breakfasts in silence.
column3: The three Icelanders, just as taciturn as their comrade the hunter, never spoke, and ate their breakfasts in silence.

column2: We were now beginning to scale the steep sides of Snaefell.
column3: We were now beginning to scale the steep sides of Snaefell.

column2: Its snowy summit, by an optical illusion not unfrequent in mountains, seemed close to us, and yet how many weary hours it took to reach it!
column3: Its snowy summit, by an optical illusion not unfrequent in mountains, seemed close to us, and yet how many weary hours it took to reach it!

column2: The stones, adhering by no soil or fibrous roots of vegetation, rolled away from under our feet, and rushed down the precipice below with the swiftness of an avalanche.
column3: The stones, adhering by no soil or fibrous roots of vegetation, rolled away from under our feet, and rushed down the precipice below with the swiftness of an avalanche.

column2: At some places the flanks of the mountain formed an angle with the horizon of at least 36 degrees; it was impossible to climb them, and these stony cliffs had to be tacked round, not without great difficulty.
column3: At some places the flanks of the mountain formed an angle with the horizon of at least thirty six degrees; it was impossible to climb them, and these stony cliffs had to be tacked round, not without great difficulty.

column2: Then we helped each other with our sticks.
column3: Then we helped each other with our sticks.

column2: I must admit that my uncle kept as close to me as he could; he never lost sight of me, and in many straits his arm furnished me with a powerful support.
column3: I must admit that my uncle kept as close to me as he could; he never lost sight of me, and in many straits his arm furnished me with a powerful support.

column2: He himself seemed to possess an instinct for equilibrium, for he never stumbled.
column3: He himself seemed to possess an instinct for equilibrium, for he never stumbled.

column2: The Icelanders, though burdened with our loads, climbed with the agility of mountaineers.
column3: The Icelanders, though burdened with our loads, climbed with the agility of mountaineers.

column2: To judge by the distant appearance of the summit of Snaefell, it would have seemed too steep to ascend on our side.
column3: To judge by the distant appearance of the summit of Snaefell, it would have seemed too steep to ascend on our side.

column2: Fortunately, after an hour of fatigue and athletic exercises, in the midst of the vast surface of snow presented by the hollow between the two peaks, a kind of staircase appeared unexpectedly which greatly facilitated our ascent.
column3: Fortunately, after an hour of fatigue and athletic exercises, in the midst of the vast surface of snow presented by the hollow between the two peaks, a kind of staircase appeared unexpectedly which greatly facilitated our ascent.

column2: It was formed by one of those torrents of stones flung up by the eruptions, called 'sting' by the Icelanders.
column3: It was formed by one of those torrents of stones flung up by the eruptions, called 'sting' by the Icelanders.

column2: If this torrent had not been arrested in its fall by the formation of the sides of the mountain, it would have gone on to the sea and formed more islands.
column3: If this torrent had not been arrested in its fall by the formation of the sides of the mountain, it would have gone on to the sea and formed more islands.

column2: Such as it was, it did us good service.
column3: Such as it was, it did us good service.

column2: The steepness increased, but these stone steps allowed us to rise with facility, and even with such rapidity that, having rested for a moment while my companions continued their ascent, I perceived them already reduced by distance to microscopic dimensions.
column3: The steepness increased, but these stone steps allowed us to rise with facility, and even with such rapidity that, having rested for a moment while my companions continued their ascent, I perceived them already reduced by distance to microscopic dimensions.

column2: At seven we had ascended the two thousand steps of this grand staircase, and we had attained a bulge in the mountain, a kind of bed on which rested the cone proper of the crater.
column3: At seven we had ascended the two thousand steps of this grand staircase, and we had attained a bulge in the mountain, a kind of bed on which rested the cone proper of the crater.

column2: Three thousand two hundred feet below us stretched the sea.
column3: Three thousand two hundred feet below us stretched the sea.

column2: We had passed the limit of perpetual snow, which, on account of the moisture of the climate, is at a greater elevation in Iceland than the high latitude would give reason to suppose.
column3: We had passed the limit of perpetual snow, which, on account of the moisture of the climate, is at a greater elevation in Iceland than the high latitude would give reason to suppose.

column2: The cold was excessively keen. The wind was blowing violently.
column3: The cold was excessively keen. The wind was blowing violently.

column2: I was exhausted.
column3: I was exhausted.

column2: The Professor saw that my limbs were refusing to perform their office, and in spite of his impatience he decided on stopping.
column3: The Professor saw that my limbs were refusing to perform their office, and in spite of his impatience he decided on stopping.

column2: He therefore spoke to the hunter, who shook his head, saying:
column3: He therefore spoke to the hunter, who shook his head, saying:

column2: _Ofvanfoer._

column2: It seems we must go higher, said my uncle.
column3: It seems we must go higher, said my uncle.

column2: Then he asked Hans for his reason.
column3: Then he asked Hans for his reason.

column2: _Mistour,_ replied the guide.
column3: underscore Mistour,underscore replied the guide.

column2: _Ja Mistour,_ said one of the Icelanders in a tone of alarm.
column3: underscore Ja Mistour,underscore said one of the Icelanders in a tone of alarm.

column2: What does that word mean? I asked uneasily.
column3: What does that word mean? I asked uneasily.

column2: Look! said my uncle.
column3: Look! said my uncle.

column2: I looked down upon the plain.
column3: I looked down upon the plain.

column2: An immense column of pulverized pumice, sand and dust was rising with a whirling circular motion like a waterspout; the wind was lashing it on to that side of Snaefell where we were holding on; this dense veil, hung across the sun, threw a deep shadow over the mountain.
column3: An immense column of pulverized pumice, sand and dust was rising with a whirling circular motion like a waterspout; the wind was lashing it on to that side of Snaefell where we were holding on; this dense veil, hung across the sun, threw a deep shadow over the mountain.

column2: If that huge revolving pillar sloped down, it would involve us in its whirling eddies.
column3: If that huge revolving pillar sloped down, it would involve us in its whirling eddies.

column2: This phenomenon, which is not unfrequent when the wind blows from the glaciers, is called in Icelandic 'mistour.'
column3: This phenomenon, which is not unfrequent when the wind blows from the glaciers, is called in Icelandic 'mistour.'

column2: _Hastigt! hastigt!_ cried our guide.
column3: underscore Hastigt! hastigt!underscore cried our guide.

column2: Without knowing Danish I understood at once that we must follow Hans at the top of our speed.
column3: Without knowing Danish I understood at once that we must follow Hans at the top of our speed.

column2: He began to circle round the cone of the crater, but in a diagonal direction so as to facilitate our progress. Presently the dust storm fell upon the mountain, which quivered under the shock; the loose stones, caught with the irresistible blasts of wind, flew about in a perfect hail as in an eruption.
column3: He began to circle round the cone of the crater, but in a diagonal direction so as to facilitate our progress. column2: Happily we were on the opposite side, and sheltered from all harm.
column3: Happily we were on the opposite side, and sheltered from all harm.

column2: But for the precaution of our guide, our mangled bodies, torn and pounded into fragments, would have been carried afar like the ruins hurled along by some unknown meteor.
column3: But for the precaution of our guide, our mangled bodies, torn and pounded into fragments, would have been carried afar like the ruins hurled along by some unknown meteor.

column2: Yet Hans did not think it prudent to spend the night upon the sides of the cone.
column3: Yet Hans did not think it prudent to spend the night upon the sides of the cone.

column2: We continued our zigzag climb.
column3: We continued our zigzag climb.

column2: The fifteen hundred remaining feet took us five hours to clear; the circuitous route, the diagonal and the counter marches, must have measured at least three leagues.
column3: The fifteen hundred remaining feet took us five hours to clear; the circuitous route, the diagonal and the counter marches, must have measured at least three leagues.

column2: I could stand it no longer.
column3: I could stand it no longer.

column2: I was yielding to the effects of hunger and cold.
column3: I was yielding to the effects of hunger and cold.

column2: The rarefied air scarcely gave play to the action of my lungs.
column3: The rarefied air scarcely gave play to the action of my lungs.

column2: At last, at eleven in the sunlight night, the summit of Snaefell was reached, and before going in for shelter into the crater I had time to observe the midnight sun, at his lowest point, gilding with his pale rays the island that slept at my feet.
column3: At last, at eleven in the sunlight night, the summit of Snaefell was reached, and before going in for shelter into the crater I had time to observe the midnight sun, at his lowest point, gilding with his pale rays the island that slept at my feet.
